channel.title: Comments on: Matlab colorbar with Gnuplot

item.title: By: yakoudbz
item.dc:creator: yakoudbz
item.description:
I think this is a much better way to define the palette:
f(x)=1.5-4*abs(x) set palette model RGB set palette functions f(gray-0.75),f(gray-0.5),f(gray-0.25)
item.content:encoded:
I think this is a much better way to define the palette:

f(x)=1.5-4*abs(x)
set palette model RGB
set palette functions f(gray-0.75),f(gray-0.5),f(gray-0.25)

item.title: By: hagen
item.dc:creator: hagen
item.description:
In reply to <a href="./../comment-page-1/index.html#comment-14777">Cindy</a>.
Hi Cindy.
Can you tell what command or file you run? The code for Fig. 1 runs fine for me.
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Cindy.

Hi Cindy.

Can you tell what command or file you run? The code for Fig. 1 runs fine for me.

item.title: By: Cindy
item.dc:creator: Cindy
item.description:
Hi, I got an error message saying error: invalid conversion from string to real N-d array error: set: expecting graphics handle as first argument
would you please tell me what could happen here?
item.content:encoded:
Hi,
I got an error message saying
error: invalid conversion from string to real N-d array
error: set: expecting graphics handle as first argument

would you please tell me what could happen here?

item.title: By: hagen
item.dc:creator: hagen
item.description: You can use <a href="http://www.gimp.org"/ rel="nofollow">GIMP</a> for this, there is a tool called color picker which does the job. This works for one color at once.
item.content:encoded: You can use GIMP for this, there is a tool called color picker which does the job. This works for one color at once.

item.title: By: xuli
item.dc:creator: xuli
item.description: Hye, Hello, Can someone help me how to extract colour from an image and display the extracted colour as colour palette?
item.content:encoded:
Hye,
Hello,
Can someone help me how to extract colour from an image and display the extracted colour as colour palette?

item.title: By: Arno Nym
item.dc:creator: Arno Nym
item.description: Thanks hagen, the »set cbrange« command was exactly what I was looking for.
item.content:encoded: Thanks hagen, the »set cbrange« command was exactly what I was looking for.

item.title: By: hagen
item.dc:creator: hagen
item.content:encoded:
Hi johannes.

For me it just works.

Fig. 2 Photoluminescence yield plotted with a blue-red-colormap (code to produce this figure, data)

The colors are automatically scaled to your data values or to the values you specify with

set cbrange [$MIN:$MAX]

item.title: By: johannes
item.dc:creator: johannes
item.description: hi, i am trying to use another color map which i found here: http://bastian.rieck.ru/blog/posts/2012/gnuplot_better_colour_palettes/. this map goes from blue over grey to red (cool to warm map). but somehow gnuplot adds some new colors like green and yellow. does gnuplot somehow interpolate missing colors? my data range is currently 0 to 4, do i have to care about that or will gnuplot automatically adapt the range of the colormap so that it fits the data range? thanks for answers or helping ideas. -johannes
item.content:encoded:
hi,
i am trying to use another color map which i found here:
http://bastian.rieck.ru/blog/posts/2012/gnuplot_better_colour_palettes/.
this map goes from blue over grey to red (cool to warm map). but somehow gnuplot adds some new colors like green and yellow. does gnuplot somehow interpolate missing colors?
my data range is currently 0 to 4, do i have to care about that or will gnuplot automatically adapt the range of the colormap so that it fits the data range?
thanks for answers or helping ideas.
-johannes
